summary: This document is a chain of emails from October 2020 and earlier (dating back to 2019) concerning the coordination and transfer of investigative materials related to the Epstein case. The correspondence involves FBI personnel and other parties discussing the scanning, transmission, and completeness of documents and CDs from the Florida investigation, indicating ongoing discovery and FOIA processes.

persons.name: AUSA
persons.context: Addressed in an email regarding a delay in processing a FOIA/media request related to the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Unit Chief Litigation Su
persons.context: Sender of an email apologizing for a delay and indicating they are waiting for a response from the FOIA team processing media requests.

events.title: FOIA/Media Request Follow-up
events.description: Email correspondence regarding a delay in processing a FOIA/media request related to the Epstein investigation, with the FBI's Litigation Support Unit awaiting a response.

events.title: Coordination on Scanned Records Transfer
events.description: Email checking on the transmission of scanned records from the Epstein investigation, questioning whether 16,000 or 29,000 pages were sent and seeking confirmation and an index of all materials.

events.title: Initial Contact on Records Information
events.description: Email following up on a conversation about records information related to the Epstein investigation, providing contact details and offering to set up another call.

keyFacts: The document reveals ongoing administrative and coordination efforts in 2020 and 2019 regarding the handling of Epstein investigation materials, specifically documents and CDs from Florida.
It indicates the involvement of the FBI's Litigation Support Unit and FOIA team in processing media requests related to the case.
The correspondence highlights concerns about the completeness of scanned records, with references to 16,000 and 29,000 pages of materials.
Multiple email addresses and names are redacted (shown as placeholders like '=', '.c â€º', '<->'), suggesting sensitive or protected identities in the communication chain.
